False Dichotomy.definition: Presenting only two options when more exist.
False Dichotomy.example: You're either with us or against us.

Ad Hominem.definition: Attacking the person instead of their argument.
Ad Hominem.example: What would you know about economics? You never even graduated college.

Straw Man.definition: Misrepresenting someone's position to make it easier to attack.
Straw Man.example: She wants to reduce military spending — I guess she wants to leave us defenseless.

Appeal to Authority.definition: Using an authority's opinion in place of evidence.
Appeal to Authority.example: This diet must work — a famous actor said it changed their life.

Bandwagon.definition: Claiming something is true simply because many believe it.
Bandwagon.example: Everyone on social media supports this candidate, so they must be the best choice.

Appeal to Ignorance.definition: Assuming a claim is true/false just because it hasn't been disproven.
Appeal to Ignorance.example: No one has proven aliens *don't* exist, so they must be real.

Slippery Slope.definition: Asserting a minor action will lead to extreme consequences without evidence.
Slippery Slope.example: If we allow kids to choose their own meals, soon they'll never listen to any rules.

Circular Reasoning.definition: Using the conclusion as a premise.
Circular Reasoning.example: The law is just because it's the law.

Hasty Generalization.definition: Making broad claims from insufficient examples.
Hasty Generalization.example: I met two rude tourists from that country, so everyone there must be rude.

Red Herring.definition: Introducing unrelated info to distract from the real issue.
Red Herring.example: Why worry about climate change when unemployment is still a problem?

False Causality.example: I wore my lucky socks and we won the game — they must have helped.

Equivocation.definition: Using a word in different senses across premises.
Equivocation.example: A feather is light. What is light can't be dark. So a feather can't be dark.

No True Scotsman.definition: Redefining a group to exclude counterexamples.
No True Scotsman.example: No true environmentalist would drive a gas-powered car.

Tu Quoque (You too!).example: You can't tell me to quit smoking — you used to smoke, too!

Appeal to Emotion / Pity.definition: Manipulating feelings instead of using logic.
Appeal to Emotion / Pity.example: You should give me the job — I've had such a rough year and really need it.

Loaded Question.definition: Asking a question that presumes something unproven.
Loaded Question.example: Why are you trying to ruin this project?

Poisoning the Well.definition: Presenting negative information to discredit someone before they speak.
Poisoning the Well.example: Before you listen to her argument, just remember she's been wrong about everything before.

Cherry-picking.definition: Only using data that supports your argument and ignoring the rest.
Cherry-picking.example: This one study shows the supplement works — ignore the other ten that say it doesn't.

Texas Sharpshooter.definition: Focusing on similarities while ignoring differences to support a point.
Texas Sharpshooter.example: These towns all had the same cancer rate and drank tap water — it must be the water.

Gambler's Fallacy.definition: Believing that past events affect future probability in random situations.
Gambler's Fallacy.example: The coin has landed heads five times — tails is due next.

Middle Ground.definition: Assuming the middle position between two extremes is always correct.
Middle Ground.example: Some say vaccines save lives, others say they're harmful — the truth must be somewhere in between.
